Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the step-parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: I stood frozen in the fluorescent-lit aisle, my stepson’s small hand still clutching the candy bar he’d tried to slip into his pocket. My heart pounded as the store manager’s eyes flicked between us, waiting for me to respond. I knew what was expected of me as a step-parent: to teach him right from wrong, to show him that stealing is never acceptable, no matter how small the item. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder that the safety briefing at the construction site was about to start. Missing it meant risking a write-up, maybe even losing my job if it happened again. My foreman had made it clear: no exceptions, everyone attends, no matter what. I looked down at my stepson, his eyes wide with fear and shame, and felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. I needed to be a good parent, to guide him through this mistake, but I also needed to keep my job, to provide for our family. My mind raced, torn between the lesson he needed and the rules I couldn’t break.
